metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Respondents (State of Madhya Pradesh)

facts.text: Notice issued by Divisional Forest Officer, Jabalpur Division for auction of various forest contracts in July 1959.

Conditions of auction specified: (a) bidder must sign sale notice and deposit Rs. 500/- earnest money per contract; (b) DFO reserves right to accept highest or any bid; (c) consideration over Rs. 3,000/- payable in four equal instalments, first immediately; (d) successful bidder signs bid-sheet immediately; (e) contracts beyond DFO power subject to competent authority sanction; (f) contract deed and security bond executed immediately; (g) failure to pay or complete formalities leads to forfeiture of earnest money, re-auction at bidder's risk, deficiency recoverable as land revenue arrears; (h) bidding deemed acceptance of conditions.
Appellant bid for two contracts at auction on July 20, 1959, and had highest bids.
Contract amount exceeded DFO's acceptance limit, referred to Chief Conservator of Forests.
After auction close, appellant signed contract form, surety signed security bond; documents sent to Chief Conservator for sanction.
Appellant raised dispute over marking of trees per verified material at auction time; dispute not settled to his satisfaction, refused to complete contract or pay first instalment.
DFO notice to appellant on July 29, 1959: complete formalities within a week or face re-auction, forfeiture, deficiency recovery.
Appellant did not pay first instalment.
On November 25, 1959, informed appellant that sale of two contracts cancelled by Chief Conservator, earnest money forfeited, contracts to be re-auctioned at his risk.
Contracts re-auctioned in January 1960; deficiency of Rs. 51,500/- in two contracts together.
Appellant asked to pay deficiency; failed to do so.
DFO letter to Tehsildar Jabalpur for recovery of Rs. 51,500/- as arrears of land revenue.

Appellant filed writ petition (M.P. No. 153 of 1961) claiming no coverage under s.82 Indian Forest Act or rr.28,29 MP Forest Contract Rules, no signed/completed contract, quash notice and stop recovery.

High Court (Full Bench) judgment dated October 5, 1961: rr.28,29 not applicable as no written contract executed; implied contract from auction conditions not hit by Art.299; recoverable under s.155(b) MP Land Revenue Code; petition dismissed.
No contract in writing signed by Chief Conservator of Forests.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court's view that Art. 299 of the Constitution does not hit an implied contract and amount could be recovered under s. 155(b) of the Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code is correct.
If not, whether the amount can be recovered as arrears of land revenue under any other provision of law.

petitioner_arguments.text: Claim for recovery of deficiency on re-sale not covered by s.82 of Indian Forest Act, 1927 or rr.28 and 29 of MP Forest Contract Rules or any other law; no signed or completed contract; cannot be recovered as arrears of land revenue.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.82 Indian Forest Act; rr.28,29 MP Forest Contract Rules

respondent_arguments.text: Recovery possible as arrears of land revenue under s.82 Indian Forest Act read with rr.28 and 29 of Forest Contract Rules in view of auction conditions accepted by appellant.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.82 Indian Forest Act; rr.28,29 MP Forest Contract Rules; auction conditions

court_reasoning.text: Art.299(1) equivalent to s.175(3) GOI Act 1935; mandatory requirements: expressed to be made by President/Governor, executed in writing by authorized person; no implied contracts possible as they would negate Art.299; precedents confirm no binding contract without compliance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No implied contract between Government and another person in view of Art.299(1); auction bidding/signing bid-sheet does not satisfy Art.299.

court_reasoning.text: No contract existed as required by Art.299; s.155(b) MP Land Revenue Code cannot apply to implied contract as no such contract exists.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court's view on s.155(b) incorrect.

court_reasoning.text: Rr.28,29 MP Forest Contract Rules apply post-written contract execution, which did not occur; s.82, s.85 Indian Forest Act and other provisions not investigated by High Court; remand for investigation if recovery possible under other laws/rules despite no formal contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State must show other provision permitting recovery per auction conditions.

holdings.text: No implied contract possible under Art.299(1); no contract existed; s.155(b) MP Land Revenue Code does not permit recovery.
Remand to High Court to investigate if recovery possible under other provisions like s.82, s.85 Indian Forest Act or rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Messrs. Karam Chand Thapar
precedents_cited.relevance: Requirements under s.175(3) GOI Act for binding government contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seth Bikhrai Jaipuria v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Mandatory nature of s.175(3); no binding contract without compliance.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Messrs. B. K. Mondal and Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: Mandatory provisions of s.175(3); s.70 Contract Act invocable only if benefit enjoyed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chaturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Prashram
precedents_cited.relevance: Confined to its facts under Representation of the People Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. A. L. Rallia Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: s.175(3) satisfied if requirements clear from correspondence, no formal document always needed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandatory for government contracts; no implied contracts possible.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Forest Act, 1927
statutes_cited.relevance: Potential basis for recovery as arrears of land revenue; requires investigation.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Forest Contract Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Apply to breaches after written contract executed; not applicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Provides recovery of moneys due under contract as land revenue arrears; does not apply without valid contract under Art.299.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Invocable against government if acted lawfully, non-gratuitously, and benefit enjoyed.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; held s.155(b) MP Land Revenue Code does not assist recovery; matter remanded to High Court to determine if any other provision of law or rules permits recovery of deficiency per auction conditions.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of recovery under s.155(b); remand for further investigation.

key_quotes.text: there can be no implied contract between the Government and another person, the reason being that if such implied contracts... were allowed, they would in effect make Art. 299(1) useless
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on Art.299 barring implied government contracts.

key_quotes.text: if the contract between Government and another person is not in full compliance with Art. 299(1) it would be no contract at all
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes nullity of non-compliant government contracts.
